contextId.occurrenceNote: These are images of oxen made of bronze. Alternate translation: “twelve large figures of bulls” or “twelve bronze oxen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: twelve oxen

contextId.occurrenceNote: “has caused it to happen.” The word “it” refers to what God had promised. Alternate translation: “has ensured that he fulfilled his promises” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: has fulfilled it

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaking in terms of David having a man implies that the man would be a descendant of David. This can be stated positively. Alternate translation: “you will always have a descendant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: You will not fail to have a man

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “in my sight” here implies that God would choose the man and the man would want to obey God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a man in my sight to sit on the throne of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that when their enemies defeated them, God’s people will have gone to live in other lands. Alternate translation: “bring them back to their own land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: bring them back to the land that you gave to them and to their ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the foreigners come because they hear about God’s greatness. Alternate translation: “who hears about your great name, your mighty hand, and your outstretched arm—if he comes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: who—because of your great name, your mighty hand, and your outstretched arm—comes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was because there were so many offerings. Alternate translation: “was not able to hold the large amount of burnt offerings, grain offerings, and fat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: was not able to hold the burnt offerings, the grain offerings, and the fat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lebo Hamath was north of Israel, and the brook of Egypt was south of Israel. These are used together to emphasize that people from every part of Israel were at the festival. Alternate translation: “from Lebo Hamath in the north to the brook of Egypt in the south” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: from Lebo Hamath to the brook of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated that the ark had been brought into King David’s house. Alternate translation: “because the ark of Yahweh was brought into that house, and wherever the ark of Yahweh has come is holy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: because wherever the ark of Yahweh has come is holy

contextId.occurrenceNote: These were statues. Alternate translation: “two statues of lions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: two lions

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Solomon’s days” refers to the time when Solomon ruled. Alternate translation: “when Solomon ruled” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in Solomon’s days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “fortresses” refers to fortified cities. That Rehoboam “fortified the fortresses” means that he built up and strengthened the defenses of these fortified cities. Alternate translation: “He strengthened the defenses of the fortified cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: He fortified the fortresses

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the fifth year of Rehoboam’s reign as king. Alternate translation: “in the fifth year that Rehoboam was king” or “in year five of King Rehoboam’s reign” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fifth year of King Rehoboam

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the eighteenth year of Jeroboam’s reign as king. Alternate translation: “In the eighteenth year that Jeroboam was king” or “in year 18 of King Jeroboam’s reign” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a reference to a united Israel as it existed in the time of David and Solomon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the kingdom of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “what are not gods” refers to the golden calves that Jeroboam had his craftsmen make. Although the priests served them as if they were gods, they were not really gods. Alternate translation: “a priest of idols that are not really gods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a priest of what are not gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since Yahweh is leading the army of Judah, Abijah speaks of the army of Israel fighting against the army of Judah as if they were fighting against Yahweh himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: do not fight against Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since the army of Judah is fighting in Yahweh’s name, Asa speaks of Zerah defeating Judah as if Zerah were to defeat Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “do not let man defeat your people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: do not let man defeat you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “the disgusting things” refers to idols. Having his people remove or destroy the idols is spoken of as if it were driving them away. Alternate translation: “got rid of the disgusting idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: drove away the disgusting things

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the army of Baasha first captured Ramah. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “captured and fortified Ramah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: built up Ramah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Asa wanted Ben Hadad to attack Israel. Ben Hadad could only do that if he broke his covenant with the king of Israel. The meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “Break your covenant with Baasha, king of Israel, and attack Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Break your covenant with Baasha, king of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that Yahweh shows people that he is strong by protecting his people. Alternate translation: “and Yahweh protects with his strength” or “so that he may show his strength by protecting” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: so that he might show himself strong on behalf of

contextId.occurrenceNote: Putting plants that smell good with the dead body was one of the burial customs of the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “sweet smelling plants prepared by people skilled in this custom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: sweet odors and various kinds of spices prepared by skilled perfumers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he did not worship the Baal idols in order to seek help from them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: did not seek the Baals

contextId.occurrenceNote: “and did not behave in the ways of the people of Israel.” This refers to how most of the people of Israel did not follow Yahweh. Alternate translation: “and did not follow the evil practices that were common in Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: not after the behavior of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he had these animals slaughtered to prepare a feast for the people. Also, Ahab himself would not have prepared the animals, but rather would have commanded his workers to do it. Alternate translation: “Ahab commanded his workers to slaughter many sheep and oxen for a feast for Jehoshaphat and the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Ahab killed many sheep and oxen for him and the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Ahab is requesting for Jehoshaphat to join him with his army to make war against Ramoth Gilead. This can be written explicitly. Also, in this question each of the kings represents themselves accompanied by their armies. Alternate translation: “Will you and your army go with my army to attack the city of Ramoth in the region of Gilead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Will you go with me to Ramoth Gilead

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies his left hand. Alternate translation: “on his left hand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: on his left

contextId.occurrenceNote: “you will know the answer to your question.” If Zedekiah’s rhetorical question is translated as a statement, this phrase may be translated to supply implicit information. Alternate translation: “you will know that the Spirit of Yahweh has spoken to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: you will know that

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that Yahweh caused some of the enemy soldiers to ambush other enemy soldiers. Alternate translation: “Yahweh set some enemy soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh set men

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to after they had destroyed them. Alternate translation: “When they had finished killing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: When they had finished with

contextId.occurrenceNote: They rejoiced because their enemies had been defeated. Alternate translation: “rejoice over their enemies’ defeat” or “rejoice because their enemies had been destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: rejoice over their enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he lived in a way that pleased Yahweh as his father had done. Here “walking” is an idiom for the way a person lives and behaves. Alternate translation: “He did things that were pleasing to Yahweh, like his father Asa had done, and he did not stop doing those things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: He walked in the ways of Asa, his father; he did not turn away from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: It may be helpful to reorder this sentence and to add implicit information. Alternate translation: “The Edomites surrounded him and his chariot commanders, but Jehoram and his army fought against them and escaped during the night” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: It was night when he rose up & surrounded him and his chariot commanders

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Philistines and the Arabians were two different nations. The Arabians lived southeast of Judah near the Cushites, and the Philistines lived west of Judah. These nations were stirred up separately. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “the spirit of the Philistines and the spirit of the Arabians who were near the Cushites” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the spirit of the Philistines and of the Arabians who were near the Cushites

contextId.occurrenceNote: The custom of the Israelites was to make a bonfire to honor the king who had died. They did not do this for Jehoram to express their contempt for him. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “did not make a bonfire to honor him as they normally did to honor kings when they died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: made no fire in his honor as they had done for his ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: They honored him enough to bury his body because he was the descendant of Jehoshaphat, who was a good king. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: they buried his corpse, because they said, “He deserves to be buried, because he was a descendant of Jehoshaphat, who tried hard to please Yahweh.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they buried him, for they said, “He is a son of Jehoshaphat, who sought Yahweh with all his heart.”

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers only to the males, because they could become king. Verse 11 confirms that the sons were the ones who were killed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: all the royal children

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Throughout chapter 23, Joash is referred to as “the king.” It may be helpful to your readers to occasionally add “King Joash” or “Joash the king” to make his identity explicit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: It may be helpful to state that command. Alternate translation: “All the others must remain in the courtyard, obeying what Yahweh has commanded” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: But all the other people must obey the commands of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This did not include the temple guards and the priests. This can be stated explicitly and in active form. Alternate translation: “You must kill anyone except the temple guards and the priests who come into the temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Whoever comes into the house, let him be killed

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Throughout chapter 23, Joash is referred to as “the king.” It may be helpful to your readers to occasionally add “King Joash” or “Joash the king” to make his identity explicit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Throughout chapter 23, Joash is referred to as “the king.” It may be helpful to your readers to occasionally add “King Joash” or “Joash the king” to make his identity explicit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The following verse indicates that they wanted the king to serve idols instead of Yahweh, and he agreed. Alternate translation: “Then they persuaded the king to do what they wanted” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Then the king listened to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that his father had done what was right in God’s eyes. Alternate translation: “just as his father, Amaziah, had done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: following the example of his father, Amaziah, in everything

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of those nations fled as the people of Israel moved into the land. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “before the people of Israel who moved into the land” or “as the people of Israel moved into the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: before the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase implies that it is Yahweh’s fierce wrath that is against Israel. The words “fierce wrath” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “Yahweh is extremely angry with the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: there is fierce wrath against Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Syrians believed Damascus to be the city where their gods dwelt, much like Yahweh dwelt in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “the gods whom the Syrians worshiped in Damascus” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the gods of Damascus

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expresses Ahaz’s opinion. Because the Syrians had defeated him and his army, Ahaz attributed his defeat to the gods whom the Syrians worshiped. Alternate translation: “gods whom he believed had enabled the Syrian army to defeat him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: gods that had defeated him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the east side of the temple. Alternate translation: “on the east side of the temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: on the east side

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple where Yahweh lives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the place where Yahweh lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: The object of worship may be supplied in translation. Alternate translation: “bowed and worshiped Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: bowed and worshiped

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since there were some priests who were already consecrated, this implies that more priests consecrated themselves. Alternate translation: “until more of the priests could consecrate themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: until the priests could consecrate themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: “as it was written that they should do.” It is implied that it was written that they should observe the Passover with large numbers of people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “as Moses had written that they should observe it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: according to what was written

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the blood of the lambs that the Levites killed. Here “received from the hand of the Levites” is a metonym for the Levites giving the blood to the priests. Alternate translation: “the blood that they received from the Levites” or “the lambs’ blood that the Levites gave to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the blood that they received from the hand of the Levites

contextId.occurrenceNote: To do something “against” instructions means to do something that is not in obedience to the instructions. If needed, the instructions can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “even though the written instructions said that they must purify themselves first” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: against the written instructions

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that Yahweh responded favorably to Hezekiah. Alternate translation: “So Yahweh responded favorably to Hezekiah” or “So Yahweh did what Hezekiah asked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: So Yahweh listened to Hezekiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Israel” probably refers to the northern tribes of Israel. The people are members of those tribes. They came to Jerusalem, which is in Judah. Alternate translation: “all the people who came together from Israel in the north” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: all the people who came together from Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the land of Israel” probably refers to the land owned by the northern tribes of Israel. Alternate translation: “the foreigners who came from the land of Israel in the north” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the foreigners who came from the land of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This seems to imply the old and the young. This can be restated to removed the nominal adjectives. Alternate translation: “those who are old and those who are young” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the important and the unimportant

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that he built these altars so people could make sacrifices and worship the stars. Also, he would not have built these altars himself, rather he would have commanded his workers to do it. Alternate translation: “He had his workers build altars in the two courtyards of the house of Yahweh so that the people could worship the stars and offer them sacrifices” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He built altars for all the stars of heaven in the two courtyards of the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit why he put his son in the fire and what happened after he did so. Alternate translation: “he burned his sons to death as an offering to his gods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he caused his sons to pass through the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh sent the army to attack Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “brought about an attack on them by” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: brought on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they were in charge of all the men who did any type of building work. Alternate translation: “These Levites were in charge of all of the men who did any kind of building work” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: These Levites were in charge of those who carried building material and all other men who worked in any way

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the place where the king stood at the temple. Alternate translation: “stood where he was supposed to stand at the entrance to the temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: stood in his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the idols that were repulsive to God. Alternate translation: “the disgusting idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the disgusting things

contextId.occurrenceNote: The readers should understand that Solomon probably commanded other people to do the actual work. Alternate translation: “that Solomon, king of Israel, commanded the people to build” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: that Solomon son of David, king of Israel built

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he restored the worship in the temple as God had intended it to be. Alternate translation: “restored proper worship to the temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: set the temple in order

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “came” can be stated as “went.” Alternate translation: “went and entered Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-go]])
contextId.quoteString: came and entered Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit is 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: “9.2 meters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit is 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: “9.2 meters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit is 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: “9.2 meters … 2.3 meters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty cubits & five cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit is 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: “9.2 meters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit is 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: “20 cubits … 10 cubits” or “9.2 meters … 4.6 meters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty cubits & ten cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit is 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: “4.6 meters … 2.3 meters … 13.8 meters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: ten cubits & five cubits & thirty cubits

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit is 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: “every 46 centimeters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: each cubit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is about 8 centimeters. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: thick as the width of a hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may convert these to modern measures. Alternate translation: “two and one-third meters long, two and one-third meters wide, and one and one-half meters high” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: five cubits long, five cubits wide, and three cubits high

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may convert this to a modern measure. A talent was about 33 kilograms. Alternate translation: “thirty-three hundred kilograms of silver and thirty-three kilograms of gold” or “about 3,300 kilograms of silver and 33 kilograms of gold” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bmoney]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: one hundred talents of silver and one talent of gold

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cor is 220 liters. Twenty thousand cors equals 4,400 kiloliters. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty thousand cors

contextId.occurrenceNote: A bath is 22 liters. Twenty thousand baths equals 440 kiloliters. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty thousand baths

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may convert this to a modern measure. The word translated here as “measure” is “cor” and is equivalent to 220 liters. Alternate translation: “10,000 measures of wheat” or “2,200 kiloliters of wheat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: ten thousand measures of wheat

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may convert this to a modern measure. The word translated here as “measure” is “cor” and is equivalent to 220 liters. Alternate translation: “10,000 measures of barley” or “2,200 kiloliters of barley” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: ten thousand measures of barley

contextId.occurrenceNote: A shekel is a unit of weight equal to about 11 grams. Alternate translation: “about 6.6 kilograms of silver … about 1.7 kilograms” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]])
contextId.quoteString: six hundred shekels of silver & 150 shekels

contextId.occurrenceNote: A talent is a unit of weight equal to about 33 kilograms. You may convert this to a modern measure. Alternate translation: “about twenty-two thousand kilograms of gold” or “about twenty-two metric tons of gold” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: 666 talents of gold

contextId.occurrenceNote: A shekel is a unit of weight equal to about 11 grams. You may convert this to a modern measure. Alternate translation: “Six and one half kilograms of gold” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]])
contextId.quoteString: Six hundred shekels of gold

contextId.occurrenceNote: A mina is about 600 grams. You may convert this to a modern measure. Alternate translation: “One and three-quarters kilograms of gold” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]])
contextId.quoteString: Three minas of gold

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may convert this to a modern measure. Alternate translation: “about the thirty-three hundred kilograms of silver” or “about the 3,300 kilograms of silver” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: about the one hundred talents

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may convert this to a modern measure. A “talent” is equivalent to 33 kilograms. Alternate translation: “100 talents of silver” or “3,300 kilograms of silver” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bweight]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: one hundred talents of silver

contextId.occurrenceNote: “day 2 of month 2.” This is the second month of the Hebrew calendar. The second day is near the middle of April on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the second day of the second month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the Festival of Shelters which is on the fifteenth day of the seventh month of the Hebrew calendar. This is near the beginning of October on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: at the feast, which was in the seventh month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “raised his hands.” This was to show that he was praying. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: spread out his hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon lifted up his hands and held them high as he knelt on the platform to pray. Spreading out his hands toward the heavens was a way of showing that he was praying to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: he spread out his hands toward the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Praying toward Yahweh’s temple shows that one is praying to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prays toward this house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Praying toward Jerusalem and the temple shows that they are praying to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: they pray to you toward this city & and toward the house

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Israel. Praying toward Israel would show that they were praying to Yahweh, the God of Israel. Alternate translation: “that they pray facing their land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: that they pray toward their land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a position of humility and worship. Alternate translation: “they lay down on the ground with their faces touching the stone pavement” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: they bowed down with their faces to the ground on the stone pavement

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is how they would show that they are shocked by what happened to the temple (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: will hiss

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet’s actions are a symbolic metaphor that illustrates the way that Ahab would defeat the Arameans. Ahab’s army will win with great strength, as a bull attacks another animal. Alternate translation: “With horns like these, your army will keep attacking the army of Aram like a bull attacks another animal, until you completely destroy them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will push the Arameans until they are consumed

contextId.occurrenceNote: These acts of worship that express humility and submission to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: bowed his head with his face to the ground & fell down before Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a symbolic act to show that they are making him king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: put the crown on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The symbolic act of giving him a scroll with the decrees shows that they expect him to obey them. It is unclear if these decrees were a portion of the law of Moses, or a separate set of rules for kings to obey. Alternate translation: “presented to him the covenant decrees that he should obey” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: gave him the covenant decrees

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a symbolic act to show that he was chosen by God to be the king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: anointed him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a symbolic action to show her great distress. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Athaliah tore her clothes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are symbolic acts of worship. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: bowed down & burned incense

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a symbolic action that indicates intense grief or sadness. Alternate translation: “he tore his clothes because he was very upset” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: he tore his clothes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a symbolic action that indicates intense grief or sadness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: torn your clothes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a tree that grows fruit that looks like figs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: the sycamore trees

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are different types of tress. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: cedar, cypress, and algum trees

contextId.occurrenceNote: two thin, round metal plates that are hit together to make a loud sound (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: cymbals

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ivory is the hard, white substance from the tusks or teeth of large animals, such as the elephant, walrus, or hippopotamus. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: ivory

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is not certain whether the word translated as “apes” here refers to apes, baboons, or monkeys. It is not certain whether the word translated as “baboons” here refers to baboons or peacocks. This can be translated more generally as “animals from far away” or “animals from Africa.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: apes and baboons

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

It may be helpful to reorder the events in these verses as in the UST. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-events]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exclamation that shows her amazement. Alternate translation: “Your people are greatly blessed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])
contextId.quoteString: How blessed are your people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exclamation that shows her amazement. Alternate translation: “your servants who constantly stand before you are greatly blessed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])
contextId.quoteString: how blessed are your servants who constantly stand before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This message is in the form of a parable. The worthless thistle represents Amaziah, and the cedar represents Jehoash. The trampling of the thistle by the beast expresses that something bad will happen to the thistle, and it will be powerless to stop it. The point of the parable is that Amaziah was foolish to challenge Jehoash. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: A thistle that was in Lebanon & trampled down the thistle

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “now” is used here to mark background information. This happened before Ahab went down to Samaria. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: Now Jehoshaphat had great riches and honor; he allied himself with Ahab

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “now” is used here to mark a break in the main story line. Here the narrator tells background information about the location of Sennacherib and his army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: now he was & with him

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated positively. Alternate translation: “he answered every question” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: there was no question that he did not answer

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “to make sure that only those who are clean could enter” or “to make sure only those who are acceptable to God could enter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: so that no one that was unclean in any way should enter

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “prayer” and “request” mean basically the same thing and emphasize that he is sincere as he makes his request. Solomon refers to himself as “your servant” to show that he respects Yahweh. This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “respect me, your servant, as I make this request” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: respect this prayer of your servant and his request

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “cry” and “prayer” mean basically the same thing and emphasize that he is sincere as he asks Yahweh to help him. Solomon refers to himself as “your servant” to show that he respects Yahweh. This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “listen to me, your servant, as I call for you to help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: listen to the cry and prayer that your servant prays before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “prayers” and “requests” mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the person is sincere as he makes his requests. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: prayers and requests

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and refer to God’s power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your mighty hand, and your outstretched arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “prayer” and “request” can be stated as verbs. Alternate translation: “to what they request when they pray to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to their prayer, their request

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words mean basically the same thing and emphasize how badly the people sinned. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: acted perversely and sinned

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “prayer” and “requests” mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the people are sincere as they make their requests. Alternate translation: “their requests” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to their prayer and to their requests

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “glad” and “joyful” mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize the intensity of joy. Alternate translation: “with very glad hearts” or “and they were very joyful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: with glad and joyful hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “commandments” and “statutes” mean basically the same thing and emphasize all that Yahweh has commanded. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: my statutes and my commandments

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “Power” and “might” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of Yahweh’s power. The word “hand” refers to possession. Alternate translation: “You possess great power” or “You have great power and might” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Power and might are in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second intensifies the first. Alternate translation: “to completely annihilate them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to completely kill them and destroy them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how long he lived. Alternate translation: “became very old” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: grew old and was full of days

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of fear. Alternate translation: “to make them very afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: to frighten them and trouble them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The second phrase intensifies the first phrase and emphasizes the earnestness of Manasseh’s prayer. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “He prayed to God and begged him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: He prayed to him; and God was begged by him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words all share similar meanings. Together they emphasize everything that Yahweh had commanded in the law. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: his commandments, his regulations, and his statutes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “stiffened his neck” and “hardened his heart” are both metaphors that mean to become stubborn. Zedekiah refusing to worship Yahweh is spoken of as if he refused to turn to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Zedekiah stubbornly refused to worship Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Zedekiah stiffened his neck and hardened his heart against turning to Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that these are loads of materials for building Yahweh’s house. Alternate translation: “to carry loads of materials” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: to carry loads

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that these are loads of materials for building Yahweh’s house. Alternate translation: “to carry loads of materials” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: to carry loads

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “stood” is understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: the Levites also stood with instruments of music of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the Levites also with instruments of music of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ellipsis may be supplied from the context. Alternate translation: “So they built the cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: So they built

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood information may be supplied. Alternate translation: “or should we not go” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: or not

contextId.occurrenceNote: They were singing to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “to sing and to praise Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: to sing and to praise

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb “went” is understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “with him went eighty priests of Yahweh, who were brave men” or “eighty priests of Yahweh, who were brave men, went with him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: with him eighty priests of Yahweh, who were brave men

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that they gave the freewill offerings. Alternate translation: “They also gave freewill offerings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: They also gave

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood they distributed the freewill offerings. Alternate translation: “They distributed freewill offerings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: They distributed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to celebrating the festival. Alternate translation: “then kept the Festival of Unleavened Bread” or “then celebrated the Festival of Unleavened Bread” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: then the Festival of Unleavened Bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a polite way to tell about him dying. Alternate translation: “He died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: He slept with his ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to “fall” is a euphemism for dying in battle. Alternate translation: “So many Cushites died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: So many Cushites fell

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “slept with his ancestors” is a euphemism for dying. Alternate translation: “Asa died during” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: Asa slept with his ancestors, dying in

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehoshaphat dying is spoken of as if he had fallen asleep. Alternate translation: “died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: slept with his ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “fall” is a euphemism for “die.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a polite way to say he died. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: slept with his ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is polite way to say that he died. Alternate translation: “So Uzziah died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: So Uzziah slept with his ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a euphemism. Alternate translation: “So Manasseh died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: So Manasseh slept with his ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “wisdom” can describe the word “words.” Alternate translation: “your wise words” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hendiadys]])
contextId.quoteString: your words and your wisdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: The narrator uses exaggeration to emphasize the great amount of silver that was in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “The king had so much silver in Jerusalem, it was like there was as much silver as there was stones on the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: The king made silver and gold as common in Jerusalem as the stones

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may refer either: (1) to the people whom Solomon called to Jerusalem and who are listed in 5:2 or (2) generally to those who traveled to Jerusalem for the feast, not necessarily to every male person who lived in Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: All the men of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “all” is a generalization meaning very many Israelites. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all the assembly of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration that emphasizes the great number of animals that were sacrificed. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “sacrificing more sheep and oxen than anyone could count” or “sacrificing very many sheep and oxen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: sacrificing sheep and oxen that could not be counted

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “all the assembly” is a generalization. It does not mean that every person of Israel was standing, but that all of the people who were gathered there were standing. Alternate translation: “while the people of Israel there were standing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: while all the assembly of Israel was standing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This generalization refers to those who were at the feast in Jerusalem, not necessarily to every person who lived in Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This generalization refers to those who were at the feast in Jerusalem, not necessarily to every person who lived in Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all Israel with him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization. Alternate translation: “everything she wanted to know” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all that was in her heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “all” here is a generalization. Alternate translation: “Kings from around the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: All the kings of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration to emphasize that there was such a great amount of silver. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: as much as the stones on the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “all” is a generalization. Alternate translation: “from many other places” or “from many other countries” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: from all the lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exaggeration means that there were more soldiers than a person could easily count. Alternate translation: “Many soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: Soldiers without number

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “all” is a generalization. The phrase means that David assembled people from all over Judah and Benjamin. Alternate translation: “He gathered together people from all over Judah and Benjamin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: He gathered all Judah and Benjamin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “all” is a generalization. The phrase means that people from all over Judah rejoiced. Alternate translation: “People all over Judah rejoiced” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: All Judah rejoiced

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization that refers to all the people who are present. Alternate translation: “All the other people who are present” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: All the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization to refer to all the people of Judah who were present in the courtyard that day. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization to show that many people participated in the event. Alternate translation: “A very large number of the people of the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: All the people of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization that means a large group of the people did this. Alternate translation: “a very large group of the people went to the temple of Baal” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all the people went to the house of Baal

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization that means he took very many people with him. Alternate translation: “a very large group of the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all the people of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is generalization to say that most of the people rejoiced. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: So all the people of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization. Some people probably did not respond this way. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: All the leaders and all the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration to emphasize the thoroughness of the slaughter. Alternate translation: “so that they were all completely destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: so that they were all broken in pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization that refers to the soldiers of Judah who survived the battle. Alternate translation: “the surviving soldiers of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: every man

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “All” is a generalization. Some people may not have wanted him to be king. Alternate translation: “The people of Judah took the 16 year-old Uzziah and made him king after his father, Amaziah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: All the people of Judah took Uzziah, who was sixteen years old, and made him king in place of his father Amaziah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization. Alternate translation: “in the same way” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: in everything

contextId.occurrenceNote: God wanted his people to offer sacrifices to him in Jerusalem. The word “every” here is an exaggeration to show how determined King Ahaz was to disobey God by offering sacrifices in many other places instead. Alternate translation: “under many green trees” or “under many green trees around the country” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: under every green tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization. Alternate translation: “many other people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all the men of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration, as there were kingdoms over which Cyrus did not rule. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all the kingdoms of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “was with him” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “God supported him” or “God helped him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: God was with him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “sang loudly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: raised their voices

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “has done exactly what he said he would do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: has carried out the word that he had said

contextId.occurrenceNote: “you who have kept your promise to your servant David my father.” To keep a promise is an idiom that means to do what one has promised. Alternate translation: “you who have done what you promised your servant David my father” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: you who have kept with your servant David my father, what you promised him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a request. To carry out what one has said is an idiom meaning to do what one has said. Alternate translation: “please do what you have promised” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: carry out what you have promised

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “listen” is an idiom for responding to prayer. Alternate translation: “please honor their prayer” or “please answer their prayer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: please listen from the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idioms “with all their heart” means “completely” and “with all their soul” means “with all their being.” These two phrases have similar meanings. Alternate translation: “completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: with all their heart and with all their soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “kept the dedication” is an idiom meaning “celebrated the dedication.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they kept the dedication of the altar

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “he successfully finished” or “he caused to be done successfully (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: he successfully carried out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being called by God’s name is an idiom meaning belonging to God. Alternate translation: “who belong to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: who are called by my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “she was completely amazed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: there was no more breath in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “every year” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: year after year

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “stand before” is an idiom for serving the king in his presence. Alternate translation: “the old men who counseled Solomon” or “the old men who attended to Solomon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the old men who had stood before Solomon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom and can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “God caused things to happen like this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: it was a turn in events brought about by God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “carry out his word” means to do what he had said he would do. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: that Yahweh might carry out his word

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “see to” is an idiom meaning to take care of something, and “house” is a metonym for David’s lineage of power and prestige. Alternate translation: “Now take care of your own kingdom, descendant of David” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Now see to your own house, David

contextId.occurrenceNote: “choice men who were soldiers.” The phrase “chosen men” is an idiom that refers to elite soldiers who were skilled in battle. Alternate translation: “of the best soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: chosen men who were soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. Alternate translation: “Yahweh spoke this message … and he said” or “Yahweh spoke these words … and he said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh came & saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “drive away” is an idiom that means to forcefully cause someone to leave. Alternate translation: “Jeroboam and his sons had forced them to leave” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Jeroboam and his sons had driven them away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that he married her. Alternate translation: “Rehoboam married Maacah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Rehoboam took Maacah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means marched against or attacked. Alternate translation: “came to attack” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: came up against

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. Alternate translation: “Yahweh spoke this message … and he said” or “Yahweh spoke these words … and he said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh came & saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that they thoroughly defeated them, or that they killed very many of the soldiers. Alternate translation: “thoroughly defeated them” or “slaughtered many of their soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: killed them with great slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “took … wives” means that he married. Alternate translation: “he married fourteen women” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: he took fourteen wives for himself

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom which means that the spirit of God influenced Azariah and enabled him to prophesy. Alternate translation: “The Spirit of God gave Azariah the ability to prophesy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The Spirit of God came on Azariah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is an idiom that refers to a person who travels anywhere away from home. Alternate translation: “for the person who traveled anywhere” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: for him who traveled away, nor for him who traveled to here

contextId.occurrenceNote: Together, these two phrases form an idiomatic expression that refers to a person’s entire being. Alternate translation: “with all their beings” or “wholeheartedly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: with all their heart and with all their soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “with all their heart” means “with complete devotion.” Alternate translation: “with complete devotion” or “wholeheartedly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: with all their heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the whole period of time that Asa lived. Alternate translation: “the whole time that he lived” or “throughout his whole life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: all his days

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Here Asa speaks of himself to represent himself along with his army. Alternate translation: “not attack me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: leave me alone

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “from the first thing that he did to the last thing that he did” or “everything he did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: from first to last

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “was with” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “God supported him” or “God helped him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh was with Jehoshaphat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the way a person lives and conducts himself is spoken of as if it were walking. For most of David’s life he lived righteously and followed Yahweh closely. Alternate translation: “lived in the first ways of his father David” or “lived righteously as has father David had done in his earlier years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: walked in the first ways of his father

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “walked” is used here as an idiom. Alternate translation: “followed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: walked in

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehoshaphat is stating his allegiance to Ahab. Alternate translation: “I offer myself and my soldiers to you to use in any way you want” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I am like you, and my people are like your people

contextId.occurrenceNote: “as surely as Yahweh is alive.” The people use this expression to show that what they say next is certainly true. This is a way of making a solemn promise. Alternate translation: “I solemnly swear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: As Yahweh lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they were standing beside him on his left side and his right side. Alternate translation: “by his right side and by his left side” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: on his right hand and on his left

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the heart represents the will. Jehoshaphat’s will is spoken of as being fixed or immovable, which means having an unchanging intention to seek God. Alternate translation: “firmly decided” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: fixed your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) Yahweh was aware of what the judges decided or (2) Yahweh would hold the judges accountable for their decisions or (3) Yahweh would help and guide them in their decisions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: he is with you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “see” is used here as an idiom to add emphasis to what is said next. They could not see the army in Hazezon Tamar from where they were speaking. Alternate translation: “They are already in Hazezon Tamar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: See, they are in Hazezon Tamar

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “determined himself to seek” or “devoted himself to seek” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: set himself to seek

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “see” here is used as an idiom to emphasize what is said next. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: See how

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to go and meet the enemy army for battle. Alternate translation: “march against” or “go to battle against” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: go down against

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to go and meet the enemy army for battle. Alternate translation: “March out against” or “Go to battle against” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Go out against

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “fallen to the ground” is an idiomatic way to say that “they were dead.” Alternate translation: “they were all dead on the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: they were dead, fallen to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: “with Jehoshaphat leading them.” The phrase “in their lead” is an idiom. King Jehoshaphat was in front of the whole army as they went back to Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Jehoshaphat in their lead

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the city of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: city of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “rise up over” something is an idiom that means to control it. Alternate translation: “taken complete control over his father’s kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: risen up over his father’s kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “struck” is an idiom that means Yahweh caused him to be sick. Alternate translation: “Yahweh caused him to suffer from an incurable disease in his intestines” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh struck him in his intestines with an incurable disease

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that refers to a set or appointed time. Alternate translation: “in the proper time” or “when the time was right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in due time

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “at all times” or (2) “wherever he goes.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: when he comes in and when he goes out

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means “as long as Jehoiada, the priest, was alive.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: all the days of Jehoiada, the priest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to the lifespan of Jehoiada. Alternate translation: “for as long as Jehoiada lived” or “throughout the lifetime of Jehoiada” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: for all the days of Jehoiada

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means he lived a long time. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: was full of days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase “whole heart” is an idiom that means “completely.” Alternate translation: “but not completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: but not with a whole heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “struck down” is an idiom that means they killed them. Alternate translation: “killed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: struck down

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means they would both be there in person, rather than communicating through messages or other people. Alternate translation: “meet each other in person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: meet each other face to face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means he had become proud. Alternate translation: “you have become proud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: your heart has lifted you up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “turn away” is an idiom that means he no longer obeyed Yahweh. Alternate translation: “stopped obeying Yahweh” or “started to disobey Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: turned away from following Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that refers to a mighty warrior. Alternate translation: “a mighty warrior” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: a powerful man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that this man was the king’s assistant who was second in command. Alternate translation: “who was the king’s second in command” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: who was next to the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “stood up against” is an idiom that means to confront or to oppose. Alternate translation: “confronted those who came back from the war” or “opposed those who came back from the war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: stood up against those who came back from the war

contextId.occurrenceNote: Taking a city is an idiom that means to conquer or to capture the city. Alternate translation: “The Philistines captured Beth Shemesh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: They took Beth Shemesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “fallen by the sword” means to die in battle. The word “sword” represents the soldiers, who used swords as their primary weapons. Alternate translation: “our fathers have died in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: our fathers have fallen by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “to stand in his presence” or (2) this is an idiom that means to serve a person of high rank. Alternate translation: “to serve him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: to stand before him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “arose” is an idiom that means that the Levites began to act. Alternate translation: “the Levites began to work” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the Levites arose

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that something is organized. Here it refers to the priestly service beginning in the temple again. Alternate translation: “was restored” or “began again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: was set in order

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the most southern and most northern parts of Israel. By referring to them this way, the writer emphasizes that all of Israel was included. Alternate translation: “from Beersheba in the south to Dan in the north” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: from Beersheba to Dan

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “carry out the command” is an idiom meaning to do what was commanded. Alternate translation: “to obey the command” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: to carry out the command

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “kept the festival” is a idiom meaning to participate in the festival or celebrate the festival. Alternate translation: “celebrate the festival” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: kept the Festival of Unleavened Bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “over” is an idiom that means to be in charge of. Alternate translation: “the official in charge of everyone who served in the house of God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the official over the house of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “under” is an idiom that means to be under someone’s authority. Alternate translation: “Eden … assisted Kore in the cities of the priests” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Under him were Eden & in the cities of the priests

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, the word **kings** could mean: (1) this is an idiom that refers to the one king of Assyria. Alternate translation: “the king of Assyria” or (2) this may refer to the king and his other leaders. Alternate translation: “the king and the other leaders of Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the kings of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “place over” means to put in charge of. “He put military commanders in charge of the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: He placed military commanders over the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lifted up” is an idiom that means to honor. Also, “in the eyes” is a metaphor that represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “the people of all the nations honored him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he was lifted up in the eyes of all nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “became the next king” or “became the king of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: king in his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “killed him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: put him to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “became the next king” or “became the king of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: king in his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “They have gathered all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: They have emptied out

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word is used here as an idiom to draw the listener’s attention to what is said next. Alternate translation: “Listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: See

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “with all his heart” means “completely” and “with all his soul” means “with all his being.” These two phrases have similar meanings. Alternate translation: “with all his being” or “with all his energy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: with all his heart and all his soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “accept the terms of the covenant” or “promise to obey the covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: stand by the covenant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “observed the Passover” or “celebrated the Passover” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: kept the Passover

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “was observed” or “was celebrated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: was kept

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “removed him at Jerusalem” means that he caused him no longer to be king in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “The king of Egypt removed him from being king in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The king of Egypt removed him at Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to things that he did for which people could accuse him of wrong. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “what people found against him” or “things that he did for which people could accuse him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: what was found against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “followed the … practices” means to do those things. Alternate translation: “they did the disgusting things that the nations did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they followed the disgusting practices of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that nobody could do anything to prevent what happened. Alternate translation: “there was no way to avoid it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: there was no help for it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “brought on them” means to cause to attack with his army. Alternate translation: “God caused the king of the Chaldeans to attack them, and he” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: God brought on them the king of the Chaldeans, who

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jehoshaphat speaks of the ironic situation. Alternate translation: “This is how they ‘repay’ us for the mercy we showed to them; they are coming to drive us out of your land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: See how they are rewarding us; they are coming to drive us out of your land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a merism. Alternate translation: “all the time” or “continually” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: day and night

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “first and last” represents the whole time of Solomon’s reign. Alternate translation: “from the beginning to the end of his reign” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: first and last

contextId.occurrenceNote: “from beginning to end.” These two words form a merism and refer to everything that Rehoboam did from the beginning of his reign to the end of his reign. Alternate translation: “everything that he did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: first and last

contextId.occurrenceNote: By mentioning both “the unimportant” and “the important soldiers,” the king meant all soldiers. Alternate translation: “Do not attack any of the soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
