Alternate translation: “Yahweh humiliated the people of Judah because of Ahaz” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh brought Judah low because of Ahaz

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of God … the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of God & the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since Ahaz was king, he may have had his workers make these high places. Alternate translation: “he had his workers make altars for him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he made for himself altars

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since Ahaz was king, he may have had his workers make these high places. Alternate translation: “he had his workers make high places to burn sacrifices” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he made high places to burn sacrifices

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since Hezekiah was king, he may have had his workers do these things. Alternate translation: “Hezekiah ordered his workers to open the doors … and to repair them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Hezekiah opened the doors & and repaired them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “Judah and Jerusalem” refer to the people who live there. Hezekiah speaks of Yahweh being angry with the people and punishing them as if his wrath were an object that fell upon them. Alternate translation: “because Yahweh was angry, he had punished the people of Judah and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the wrath of Yahweh had fallen on Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” represents the thoughts and intentions. Hezekiah speaks of deciding to do something as if that thing were in his heart. Alternate translation: “it is my intention” or “I have decided” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it is in my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of Yahweh … the courtyard of the temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Yahweh & the courtyard of the house

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the porch of Yahweh” refers to the porch of the temple. “They reached” means that they began to cleanse this section. Alternate translation: “they had begun to cleanse the porch of Yahweh’s temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they reached the porch of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hand” often represents power or authority. Here it represents the kings’ cruel authority to force people to go to other countries. Alternate translation: “who have escaped from the power of the kings of Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who have escaped from the hand of the kings of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his holy place” refers to God’s temple in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “come to his temple in Jerusalem for it is holy” or “come to his temple in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: come into his holy place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents a family or descendants. Alternate translation: “a descendant of Zadok” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: of the house of Zadok

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. The phrase “under the hand” is an idiom that means to be under someone’s authority. Alternate translation: “were managers whom Konaniah and Shimei his brother supervised” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: were managers under the hand of Konaniah and Shimei his brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” refers to a person’s will and desire. Alternate translation: “he performed it with all his will” or “he was completely committed to what he did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he performed it with all his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” represents the people there. Alternate translation: “to fight against the people of Jerusalem” or “to fight against the army of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to fight against Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “arm” represents strength, and “flesh” represents humanity. Alternate translation: “are only those with human power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: is only an arm of flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “from the power of the king of Assyria” or “from the king of Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from the hand of the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” and “Jerusalem” represent the people who live there. Alternate translation: “commanded the people of Judah and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: commanded Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “from my power” or “from me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: out of my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “from my power” or “from me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: out of my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes that humans made these idols with their own hands and are therefore worthless. Alternate translation: “which are merely idols that men have made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: which are merely the work of men’s hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heaven” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “cried to Yahweh for help” or “pleaded to Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: cried out to heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “from the power of Sennacherib … from the power of all others” or “from Sennacherib … from all others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from the hand of Sennacherib & from the hand of all others

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” is a metonym that represents a person’s inner being. Here “heart was lifted up” is an idiom that means to become proud. Alternate translation: “he became proud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: his heart was lifted up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The readers should understand that Hezekiah probably commanded other people to do the actual work. Alternate translation: “Hezekiah who ordered his workers to stop up … and to build a tunnel so that the water would flow down” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Hezekiah who also stopped up & and who brought them straight down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents a person’s inner being. Alternate translation: “to reveal Hezekiah’s true character” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to know all that was in his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh would have commanded his workers to do the building for him. Alternate translation: “he had the high places rebuilt … he had altars built … he had Asherah poles made” or “he had his workers rebuild the high places … he had them build altars … he had them make Asherah poles” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he rebuilt the high places & he built altars & he made Asherah poles

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name is a metonym for the person. Alternate translation: “Jerusalem is where I will forever make known who I am” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: It is in Jerusalem that my name will be forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh probably did not do the work. His servants would have done the work. Alternate translation: “Manasseh had ordered his servants to make” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he had made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is represented by his “name.” Alternate translation: “where I want people to worship me forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: that I will put my name forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” refers to the people who had lived in the land of Canaan before the Israelites had arrived. Alternate translation: “even more than the people whom Yahweh had destroyed as the people of Israel advanced through the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: even more than the nations that Yahweh had destroyed before the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Manasseh being taken as a prisoner is represented by him being bound by chains and fetters. Fetters were chains placed around the feet. Alternate translation: “seized Manasseh, bound him in chains, and took him as a prisoner to Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: took Manasseh in chains, bound him with fetters, and took him off to Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh did not do the building and construction himself, rather, he commanded his workers to do it. Alternate translation: “Manasseh commanded his workers to build … They surrounded … and raised … He commanded his workers to put” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Manasseh built & He surrounded & and raised & He put

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh did not do the building and construction himself; rather, he commanded his workers to do it. Alternate translation: “Manasseh commanded his workers to take away … they had previously built … and to throw” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He took away & he had built & and threw

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh did not do the building and construction himself, rather, he commanded his workers to do it. Alternate translation: “He commanded them to rebuild” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He rebuilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “he commanded the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he commanded Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Manasseh did not do the building and construction himself, rather, he commanded his workers to do it. Alternate translation: “the place where he had the high places built and the Asherah poles and the carved figures set up” or “the places where he commanded his workers to build the high places and to set up the Asherah poles and carved figures” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the places where he had built high places and set up the Asherah poles and the carved figures

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah probably commanded his workers to do much or all of this work. Alternate translation: “he had them cut apart … He commanded them to break … He had them scatter” or “he and his workers cut apart … He and his workers broke … He and his workers scattered” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: he cut apart & He broke & He scattered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah probably commanded his workers to do much or all of this work. Alternate translation: “He commanded them to burn” or “He and his workers burned” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He burned

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah would have commanded his workers to do these things. Alternate translation: “He commanded his workers to break down the altars, to beat … to cut apart” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He broke down the altars, beat & cut apart

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “they” refers to the men that Josiah had sent to Hilkiah the high priest. They first gave the money to him and then he distributed it to the men who supervised the building. Alternate translation: “Then Hilkiah entrusted” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They entrusted

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “words” represents the laws. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the laws in the book that Hilkiah has found” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the words of the book that has been found

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “this place” refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “on these people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: on this place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents a person’s inner being. Feeling sorry is spoken of as if the heart were tender. Alternate translation: “because you felt sorry” or “because you repented” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: because your heart was tender

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah would have commanded his workers to do this. Alternate translation: “Josiah commanded his workers to take away all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Josiah took away all

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. Alternate translation: “the families that are descendants of your ancestors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your ancestral houses

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. Alternate translation: “the families that were the descendants of their ancestors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: ancestral houses of the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “house” refers to the house of Babylon, where “house” is a metonym for the kingdom. The kingdom is a synechdoche representing the Babylonian army. Alternate translation: “against the house of Babylon, with whom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: against the house with which

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Judah” and “Jerusalem” represent the people who live there. Alternate translation: “All the people of Judah and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: All Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “land” represents the people who lived there. Alternate translation: “fined the people of the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: fined the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “him” refers to Jehoiakim. Jehoiakim represents either Jerusalem or the nation of Judah. Alternate translation: “attacked Jerusalem” or “attacked Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: attacked him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since Nebuchadnezzar was king, he may have had his soldiers do this. Alternate translation: “Nebuchadnezzar also had his soldiers carry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar also carried

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “mouth” represents the words that Yahweh spoke. Alternate translation: “who spoke the words that Yahweh spoke to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who spoke from the mouth of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king probably did not personally kill their young men. Rather, his army killed them. Alternate translation: “whose army killed their young men with swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who killed their young men with the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” is a metonym for the power to defeat them. Alternate translation: “God allowed the Chaldean army to defeat them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: God gave them all into his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the temple of God … the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of God & the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the king” refers to his soldiers whom he ordered to do the work. The phrase “carried away” is an idiom that means to forcefully bring them to Babylon. Alternate translation: “The king had his army forcefully take to Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The king carried away to Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “house” represents a temple. Alternate translation: “to build a temple for him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to build a house for him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences mean the same thing. Together they emphasize how bad the people’s actions were. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: We have acted perversely and sinned & e have behaved wickedly

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. The phrase “bowed down to them” describes the posture that people used in worship. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: bowed down to them and worshiped them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. The yoke metaphor emphasizes the fact that Solomon had treated them harshly. Alternate translation: “make the hard work that your father gave us easier, and do not treat us as harshly as he did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: make your father’s hard work easier, and lighten the heavy yoke that he put on us

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings. The words “faces” and “backs” represent the people who turned so that their faces were away from the temple and their backs were towards it. Alternate translation: “turned away from the place where Yahweh lives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: turned away their faces from the place where Yahweh lives, and turned their backs on it

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and imply that God responded favorably to their prayer. Alternate translation: “God responded favorably to their prayer, which he heard in heaven, the holy place where he lives” or “God, who lives in the holy heaven, heard their prayer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Their voice was heard & their prayer went up to heaven, the holy place where God lives

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements mean basically the same thing. They are polite ways of saying he will die. Alternate translation: “so I will allow you to die and be buried peacefully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: see, I will gather you to your ancestors & ou will be gathered to your grave in peace

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here land that does not produce much is spoken of as though it were sick. Alternate translation: “make their land good again” or “make their land produce good crops” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: heal their land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh no longer being angry with Rehoboam is spoken of as if Yahweh’s anger were a person who turned away from Rehoboam. Alternate translation: “Yahweh was no longer angry with him and so did not destroy him completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh’s anger turned away from him, so as not to destroy him completely

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author writes of anger as if it were a person that can turn away from people. God’s anger turning away from them represents him no longer being angry with them. Alternate translation: “so that he will no longer be angry with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: so that his fierce anger may turn away from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people were supposed to obey the Sabbath law by not farming the land every seventh year. This phrase speaks about this as if the land were a person that would obey the Sabbath law and rest. Alternate translation: “until the land had rested according to the Sabbath law” or “until, as required by the Sabbath law, no one had farmed the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: until the land should have enjoyed its Sabbath rests

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “it” refers to the land. The land is spoken of as if it were a person who observed the Sabbath. Alternate translation: “The requirements of the Sabbath law were fulfilled as long as the land lay abandoned” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: It observed its Sabbath for as long as it lay abandoned

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “judge” means to govern or rule. Solomon uses a question to state that it is impossible to rule over so many people without God’s help. Alternate translation: “no one can judge all of your countless people without your help.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: who can judge your people, who are so many in number?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon uses a question to emphasize that no one is able or worthy to build a house for God. Alternate translation: “no one is able to build a house for God because not even the universe or heaven is big enough to contain him. I am not worthy to build a house for him, except as a place to offer sacrifices to him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: who is able to build God a house, since the entire universe and even heaven itself cannot contain him? Who am I to build him a house, except to burn sacrifices before him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings of this question are: (1) Solomon is asking a real question and expecting an answer or (2) the question is rhetorical and Solomon is emphasizing that God is too big and mighty to live on earth. Alternate translation: “But it surely cannot be that God will actually live on the earth!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: But will God actually live with mankind on the earth?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses the question to remind the readers that other people had written about Solomon. It can be expressed in active form Alternate translation: “they are written … (which also had information about Jeroboam son of Nebat.)” or “people have written about them … (which also had information about Jeroboam son of Nebat).” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: are they not written & (which also had information about Jeroboam son of Nebat)?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people use this question and statement to imply that since they do not belong to David’s family, they are not obligated to support David’s grandson, King Rehoboam. Alternate translation: “We have no share in David. We will not have anything to do with the descendants of the son of Jesse” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: What share do we have in David? We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse

contextId.occurrenceNote: Abijah asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the positive answer that it anticipates. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You know very well … by a formal covenant.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do you not know & by a formal covenant?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Abijah asks this rhetorical question to rebuke the people and to emphasize the positive answer that it anticipates. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “But you drive out … as the people of other lands do.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: But did you not drive out & as the people of other lands do?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hanani uses this rhetorical question to remind Asa of a previous victory. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “The Cushites and the Libyans were a huge army, with very many chariots and horsemen.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Were not the Cushites and the Libyans a huge army, with very many chariots and horsemen?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ahab asks this question out of frustration to rebuke Micaiah. Alternate translation: “Many times I have required … in the name of Yahweh.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How many times must I require & in the name of Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ahab asks this question to emphasize that he had spoken the truth about Micaiah. Alternate translation: “I told you … but only disaster!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Did I not tell you & but only disaster?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zedekiah asks this sarcastic question to insult and rebuke Micaiah. Alternate translation: “Do not think that Yahweh’s Spirit left me to speak to you!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Which way did the Spirit of Yahweh take to go from me to speak to you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These questions expect negative answers to make the point that Jehoshaphat should not have helped Ahab. Alternate translation: “You should not help the wicked! You should not love those who hate Yahweh!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should you be helping the wicked? Should you be loving those who hate Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehoshaphat uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that God is in heaven and his authority over all things. This question can be written as statement. Alternate translation: “you are indeed God in heaven and the ruler over all the kings of the earth.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: are you not God in heaven? Are you not the ruler over all the kingdoms of the nations?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehoshaphat uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that God drove their enemies from their land and gave it to the Israelites. This question can be written as statement. Alternate translation: “It was you who drove out those who lived in this land for the sake of your people Israel and who gave it permanently to the descendants of Abraham.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Our God, did you not drive out the inhabitants of this land & to the descendants of Abraham?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is used as a request. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “please judge them.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: will you not judge them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: King Joash asks this rhetorical question to accuse Jehoiada of not doing his duty. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have neglected your duty. I told you to require the Levites … covenant decrees, but you have not done it.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why have you not required the Levites & covenant decrees?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zechariah asked this rhetorical question to rebuke the people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You are transgressing the commandments of Yahweh, so that is why you cannot prosper.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do you transgress the commandments of Yahweh, so that you cannot prosper?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet uses this rhetorical question to rebuke Amaziah for worshiping the powerless gods of the people he had defeated. Here the word “hand” is a metonym for power. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have worshiped the gods of a people that did not even save their own people from your power, King Amaziah.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Why have you sought after the gods of a people who did not even save their own people from your hand?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king used these rhetorical questions to rebuke the prophet for speaking against him. The questions can be translated as statements. Alternate translation: “We certainly did not appoint you to be one of my advisors. So stop talking! If you say anything more, I will tell my soldiers to kill you!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Have we made you an advisor to the king? Stop! Why should you be killed?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehoash used this rhetorical question to warn Amaziah not to fight with him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “you should not cause yourself trouble and fall, both you and Judah with you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: why should you cause yourself trouble and fall, both you and Judah with you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is used to remind the reader that what happened to Amaziah is well-known. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “All of the matters concerning Amaziah, behold, are written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: As for the other matters & are they not written in the book of the kings of Judah and Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Oded asks this rhetorical question to rebuke the army of Israel and to emphasize the positive answer that the question anticipates. Alternate translation: “But you yourselves are guilty of sins of your own against Yahweh your God.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: But are you not guilty of sins of your own against Yahweh your God?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people use a rhetorical question to emphasize that they do not want the kings of Assyria to find their water. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “We do not want the kings of Assyria to come here and find a lot of water.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why should the kings of Assyria come and find a lot of water?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sennacherib uses a rhetorical question to cause the people to think about their situation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You are not able to endure a siege in Jerusalem.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What are you relying on in order to endure a siege in Jerusalem?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sennacherib uses a rhetorical question to cause the people of Jerusalem to think about their situation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Hezekiah is misleading you … king of Assyria.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is not Hezekiah misleading you & king of Assyria’?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sennacherib uses a rhetorical question to cause the people of Jerusalem to think about their situation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You know very well what … lands!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do you not know what & lands?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sennacherib uses a rhetorical question to cause the people of Jerusalem to think about their situation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There was no god … power!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Were the gods & power?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sennacherib uses a rhetorical question to cause the people of Jerusalem to think about their situation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There was no god among all the gods … who … hand!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Among all the gods & was there any god who & hand?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sennacherib uses a rhetorical question to cause the people of Jerusalem to think about their situation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is no reason your God should be able … power!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why should your God be able & power?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sennacherib uses a rhetorical question to cause the people of Jerusalem to think about their situation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Your God will certainly not be able to rescue you from my hand!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How much less will your God rescue you from my hand?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Necho uses this rhetorical question to tell Josiah that he is not in conflict with him and that Josiah should not attack him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have no reason to attack me, king of Judah.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What have I to do with you, king of Judah?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes the great number of Israelites. Alternate translation: “countless people” or “very many people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: a people as numerous as the dust of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of the army are compared to sheep that have no one to lead them because their shepherd, the king, has died. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like sheep who have no shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Solomon” represents all the people with him. Also “came” can be stated as “went.” Alternate translation: “So Solomon and the people with him went to Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-go]])
contextId.quoteString: So Solomon came to Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Huram represents all who worked on the temple. Alternate translation: “Huram and the other workers finished the work that they did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Huram finished the work that he did

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Huram represents all who worked on the temple. Alternate translation: “Huram and the other workers had made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He had made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Huram, who is also called Huram-Abi, represents all those who worked with him. Alternate translation: “They also made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He also made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Huram, who is also called Huram-Abi, represents all those who worked with him. Alternate translation: “Huram-Abi and his craftsmen made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Huram-Abi made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of commanding the people to build the temple and telling them how to do it as if he himself had built it. Alternate translation: “I and your people have built you a lofty residence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I have built you a lofty residence

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of commanding the people to build the temple and telling them how to do it as if he himself had built it. Alternate translation: “this temple that your people have built under my leadership” or “this house that I and your people have built” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: this temple that I have built

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “head” refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “on him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: upon his own head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of commanding the people to build the temple and telling them how to do it as if he himself had built it. Alternate translation: “this house that your people have built under my leadership” or “this house that I and your people have built” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the house that I have built

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of commanding the people to build the temple and telling them how to do it as if he himself had built it. Alternate translation: “the house that your people have built under my leadership” or “the house that I and your people have built” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the house that I have built

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon represents his whole fighting army. Alternate translation: “Solomon’s army attacked the town of Hamathzolbah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Solomon attacked Hamathzobah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Tadmor was a city north of Israel, in modern-day Syria. The author writes of Solomon commanding the people to build Tadmor as if Solomon himself built it. Alternate translation: “Solomon caused the town of Tadmor in the wilderness to be rebuilt” or “Solomon commanded, and the people built the town of Tadmor in the wilderness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He built Tadmor in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “my eyes” emphasizes that she herself saw it. Alternate translation: “now I have seen it for myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: now my eyes have seen it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents Shishak himself. Alternate translation: “by means of Shishak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: by means of Shishak’s hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The names of the kings represent the armies that they led. Alternate translation: “the wars in which Rehoboam’s army and Jeroboam’s army constantly engaged” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the constant wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam

contextId.occurrenceNote: The names of the kings represent the armies that they led. Alternate translation: “There was war between the army of Abijah and the army of Jeroboam” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: There was war between Abijah and Jeroboam

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” represents the people who work. Alternate translation: “do not become weak as you work” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: do not let your hands be weak

contextId.occurrenceNote: The heart represents the person. Alternate translation: “Asa was completely devoted” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Asa’s heart was completely devoted

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Asa’s armies are represented by their commanders. Alternate translation: “sent his armies to attack the cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: sent the commanders of his armies against the cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Asa represents himself and his army. “his work” refers to other work that his workers were doing in Ramah. Alternate translation: “he commanded his army to stop fortifying Ramah and doing other work there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: he stopped building up Ramah, and let his work cease

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that king Asa’s army was able to defeat the opposing army. Alternate translation: “he gave your army victory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: he gave you victory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jehoshaphat prepared the army for battle. Alternate translation: “prepared the army to be able to battle Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: strengthened himself against Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the king is represented by his “heart” to emphasize his will and desires. Alternate translation: “He” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: His heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jehoshaphat represents his army. Alternate translation: “against Jehoshaphat’s army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: against Jehoshaphat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here about refers to himself accompanied by his army as himself. Alternate translation: “should we not” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: should I not

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the kings represent themselves accompanied by their armies. Alternate translation: “Ahab, the king of Israel, and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah led their armies up against” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Ahab, the king of Israel, and Jehoshaphat, the king of Judah, went up against

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jehoshaphat” represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: “came against Jehoshaphat’s army to do battle” or “came to fight against Jehoshaphat and his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: came against Jehoshaphat to do battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s presence is represented by his “name.” Alternate translation: “your presence is here in this house” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: your name is in this house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their “eyes” to emphasize that they are directing their attention to God. Alternate translation: “we are looking to you for help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: our eyes are on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a reference to every man in the army. Alternate translation: “every soldier of Judah and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: every man of Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Other people helped Jehoram build these high places all over the mountains of Judah. Alternate translation: “Jehoram and the people had also built high places” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Jehoram had also built high places

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jehoram refers to Jehoram and the people of Judah that he ruled. Alternate translation: “against Jehoram and the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: against Jehoram

contextId.occurrenceNote: The reader should understand that Hazael did not fight alone, but that he took his army with him. Alternate translation: “to fight against Hazael, king of Aram, and his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: to fight against Hazael, king of Aram

contextId.occurrenceNote: Uzziah did not do this alone. Alternate translation: “It was he who ordered Elath to be rebuilt” or “It was he who supervised the rebuilding of Elath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: It was he who rebuilt Elath

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Uzziah” represents himself and his army that he led. Alternate translation: “Uzziah led his army out to fight against the Philistines” or “Uzziah and his army went out and fought against the Philistines” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Uzziah went out and fought against the Philistines

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the pronouns “He” and “him” represent Uzziah and his army. Alternate translation: “Uzziah and his army broke down … they built cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He broke down & he built cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the pronouns “He” and “him” represent Uzziah and his army. Alternate translation: “God helped them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: God helped him

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to translate so that the reader understands that Jothan led his army to fight. Alternate translation: “He also led his army to fight with the king of the people of Ammon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He fought also with the king of the people of Ammon

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to translate so that the reader understands that the king of Ammon led his army to fight. Alternate translation: “with the king of Ammon and his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: with the king of the people of Ammon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” represents the person who was willing. Alternate translation: “who were willing” or “who desired” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: who had a willing heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim and Manasseh were two of the tribes in the northern part of Israel. Here the phrase “Ephraim and Manasseh” refers to the people who belonged to all ten of the northern tribes of Israel. Alternate translation: “the northern tribes of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim and Manasseh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib represents his army. Alternate translation: “Sennacherib, king of Assyria, and his army came … They camped” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Sennacherib, king of Assyria, came & He camped

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib also represents his army. Alternate translation: “that Sennacherib and his army had come and that they intended” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: that Sennacherib had come and that he intended

contextId.occurrenceNote: The readers should understand that Hezekiah probably commanded other people to do the actual work. Alternate translation: “Hezekiah took courage and commanded the people to build up … They built … They also … they made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Hezekiah took courage and built up & He built & He also & he made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” is a part of “Judah.” Alternate translation: “the people of Judah and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The commanders were accompanied by their soldiers. Alternate translation: “the commanders of the army of the king of Assyria and their soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the commanders of the army of the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to some on the money that was entrusted to Hilkiah. Alternate translation: “some of the money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the money

contextId.occurrenceNote: The supervisors and workmen are represented by their “hand” to emphasize their possession. Alternate translation: “to the supervisors and the workmen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: into the hand of the supervisors and to the workmen

contextId.occurrenceNote: “to Jerusalem” This refers to the city of Jerusalem which represents the whole land of Judah. Alternate translation: “on Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: on this place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” represents the whole person. Also, the phrase “will not see” represents not experiencing something. Alternate translation: “you will not experience” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your eyes will not see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Josiah’s life is represented by his “days.” Alternate translation: “For all of his life” or “As long as Josiah was alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: For all of his days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” refers to Moses himself. Yahweh used Moses as the agent to deliver his command. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “to obey all of the commands that Yahweh gave to the people through Moses” or “to do everything that Yahweh commanded Moses to tell the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: to do according to the word of Yahweh that was given by the hand of Moses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” refers to the Levites. Alternate translation: “the blood that the Levites gave them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the blood that they received from the Levites’ hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here both Josiah and Necho represent themselves accompained by their armies. Alternate translation: “Josiah and his army went to fight against Necho and his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Josiah went to fight against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the king Josiah represents his kingdom. Alternate translation: “I am not fighting your kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I am not coming against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “him” refers to Necho who represents himself accompanied by his army. Alternate translation: “fight with the army of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is represented by his “mouth” to emphasize his speech. Alternate translation: “that had come from God” or “that God had said to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: that had come from the mouth of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “he” refers to Josiah who represents himself accompanied by his army. Alternate translation: “so he and his army went” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: so he went

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the noun “word” can be translated with the verb “spoke.” The word “mouth” represents Jeremiah. Alternate translation: “what Yahweh spoke through Jeremiah” or “the word from Yahweh that Jeremiah spoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh by the mouth of Jeremiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the noun “word” can be translated with the verb “spoke.” The word “mouth” represents Jeremiah. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “so that what Yahweh spoke through Jeremiah might happen” or “so that the word from Yahweh that Jeremiah spoke might happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: so that the word of Yahweh by the mouth of Jeremiah might be carried out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Motivating the spirit is a synecdoche for making someone want to act. Alternate translation: “Yahweh made Cyrus, king of Persia, want to act” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh motivated the spirit of Cyrus, king of Persia

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hiram refers to Solomon as “my master” and to himself and his own people as “his servants.” This is a way of showing respect. Alternate translation: “of which you, my master, have spoken, please send these things to us, your servants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: of which my master has spoken, let him send these things to his servants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks to Yahweh as if he were speaking to someone else to show that he respects Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Yahweh, you have said that you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh has said that he

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Solomon speaks about God in the third person to show his great respect for God. It can be stated in the second person. Alternate translation: “But will you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon refers to himself as “your servant” to show that he respects Yahweh. This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “the prayer that I, your servant, pray toward this place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solomon speaks of himself as “your servant” to show that he respects Yahweh. This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: “So listen to my requests and the requests of your people Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: So listen to the requests of your servant and of your people Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Jehoshaphat speaks of himself in the third person. This can be translated in the first person. Alternate translation: “of all my royal matters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithfully” or “faithful.” Alternate translation: “You have greatly and faithfully loved David” or “You have been very faithful to David” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be restated to remove the abstract nouns “wisdom” and “knowledge.” Alternate translation: “cause me to be wise and to know many things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be restated to remove the abstract nouns “wisdom” and “knowledge.” Alternate translation: “I will now cause you to be wise and to know many things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I will now give you wisdom and knowledge

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Importation” is the act of bringing something into one country from another country. This can be stated as a verb. Alternate translation: “As for the horses Solomon imported from Egypt and Kue” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be restated to remove the abstract nouns “prudence” and “understanding.” Alternate translation: “who is very intelligent and understands many things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **understanding**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “understands” or “wise.” Alternate translation: “who understand many things” or “who is very wise” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **covenant loyalty**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithful.” Alternate translation: “for he is faithful forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **forgiveness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “ask you to forgive them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **covenant loyalty**, you can express the same idea with the adjective “loyal” and the verb “promise.” Alternate translation: “God will always be loyal to us because of his covenant” or “God will always faithfully do for us what he promised” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “justice” and “righteousness” can be expressed with the words “fairly” and “righteously.” Alternate translation: “for you to rule fairly and righteously” or “for you to do what is just and right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “terror” can be expressed with the adjective “afraid.” Also, this speaks of the people becoming afraid as if the terror were something that fell upon them. contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **good**, you can express the same idea with an adjective. Alternate translation: “you have done some good things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “iniquity,” “favoritism,” and “bribe” can be translated using the verbs “sin,” “favor,” and “bribe.” Alternate translation: “Yahweh our God will not sin or favor one person over another in judgment or be bribed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **anger**, you can express the same idea with the adjective “angry.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will be angry with you and your brothers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “rescue” can be expressed as a verb. Alternate translation: “Yahweh rescue you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **destruction**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **horror**, you can express the same idea with the words “horrified” or “horrible.” The author writes of what God did to their ancestors in terms of how other people would react when the saw what God did. contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithfully.” Alternate translation: “After Hezekiah faithfully did all the things Yahweh commanded him to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “gained complete control over his kingdom” or “ruled powerfully over his kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “when the workers cast the sea itself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “They observed this Passover” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: This Passover was kept

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the good deeds that he did” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: his good deeds done

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the words” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: what is written

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “and men have written of all his deeds … in the book” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: and his deeds & are written in the book

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “someone has written them in the book” or “you can read of them in the book” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they are written in the book

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Israel, God’s people.” The phrase “his people” emphasizes God’s faithfulness to Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-distinguish]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel, his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase tells why they should have worshiped God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-distinguish]])
contextId.quoteString: who had brought their ancestors out of the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase adds information about the descendants of those that Solomon had made into forced laborers. Alternate translation: “and their descendants are still forced laborers even now” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-distinguish]])
contextId.quoteString: which they are to this day

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases tell why people should praise Yahweh. Alternate translation: “because he has taken pleasure in you and placed you on his throne” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-distinguish]])
contextId.quoteString: who has taken pleasure in you, who placed you on his throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “good” here is a reminder to the people that Yahweh is kind. Alternate translation: “Yahweh, who is good” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-distinguish]])
contextId.quoteString: the good Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was the reason that he spoke encouragingly to them. Alternate translation: “because they understood the service of Yahweh” or “because they served Yahweh skillfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-distinguish]])
contextId.quoteString: who understood the service of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “we” refers to Ahab, Jehoshaphat, and their armies but not to Micaiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
contextId.quoteString: should we go

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “possession” means possessions in general. Alternate translation: “to his own property” or “to his own home” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-genericnoun]])
contextId.quoteString: to his own possession

contextId.occurrenceNote: When Solomon was speaking, these hypothetical situations had not happened, but Solomon knew that they might happen in the future. Use the form in your language for talking about events that have not happened but might happen in the future. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: Suppose that your people go out & suppose that they pray

contextId.occurrenceNote: When Solomon was speaking, these hypothetical situations had not happened, but Solomon knew that they might happen in the future. Use the form in your language for talking about events that have not happened but might happen in the future. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: Suppose they sin & suppose that you are angry

contextId.occurrenceNote: When Solomon was speaking, these hypothetical situations had not happened, but Solomon knew that they might happen in the future. Use the form in your language for talking about events that have not happened but might happen in the future. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: suppose they realize & suppose that they repent & Suppose that they say

contextId.occurrenceNote: When Solomon was speaking, these hypothetical situations had not happened, but Solomon knew that they might happen in the future. Use the form in your language for talking about events that have not happened but might happen in the future. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: Suppose that they return & suppose that they pray

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes something that would not happen. Yahweh had already told Micaiah that the king would not return safely. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: If you return safely

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to wicked people in general. Alternate translation: “wicked people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nominal adjective “good” can be translated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “because he had done good things in Judah for God and for God’s temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: because he had done good in Israel, toward God, and to God’s house

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to dead people. Alternate translation: “dead people” or “those who are dead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the dead

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “set” is a metonym for choosing, and the words “over themselves” is a metonym for “to rule them.” Alternate translation: “chose a king to rule over them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: set a king over themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: The use of the reflexive “yourself” emphasizes that this is a personal judgment on Jehoram. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: You yourself

contextId.occurrenceNote: The reflexive pronoun emphasizes that Yahweh was the one to whom they should turn. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: to himself, Yahweh
